description: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a collection of cloud-based services offered by Amazon.com, which provides access to hosted resources. The services range from hosted virtual servers and storage to DNS and Database hosting. AWS gives the chance for private companies to take advantage of the investment in infrastructure that Amazon has made including massive generators, their five different internet service providers and data centers. This series of videos is designed to introduce the viewer to some of the AWS products and demonstrate the basic skills required to deploy and maintain them.
name: Amazon Web Services
subtitle: Web Services

episodes.title: Intro To Amazon Web Services
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:23,434 --> 00:00:33,562
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,562 --> 00:00:36,607
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening and

3
00:00:36,607 --> 00:00:38,800
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:38,800 --> 00:00:41,040
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:41,040 --> 00:00:44,580
Coming at you today with
Amazon Web Services.

6
00:00:44,580 --> 00:00:47,030
Now this is our first episode for
Amazon Web Services, and

7
00:00:47,030 --> 00:00:51,290
what I wanted to do is take a minute
to do an overview of the whole service.

8
00:00:51,290 --> 00:00:54,090
What the product is, and
kinda give you an idea of

9
00:00:54,090 --> 00:00:57,440
some of the things that we're gonna
be covering in the upcoming episodes.

10
00:00:57,440 --> 00:01:01,120
There are many,
many people out there that leverage AWS.

11
00:01:01,120 --> 00:01:03,330
And for the people who don't use it,

12
00:01:03,330 --> 00:01:06,690
you might be looking at it and
saying man, I'm missing out on something?

13
00:01:06,690 --> 00:01:10,150
And the short answer is yes, you're
actually missing out on something cool.

14
00:01:10,150 --> 00:01:13,515
But there are other offerings out there
that you might choose to go with too.

15
00:01:13,515 --> 00:01:15,490
But Amazon is one of
the more popular ones.

16
00:01:15,490 --> 00:01:20,080
So let's talk about what it is, and
why they're as popular as they are, right.

17
00:01:20,080 --> 00:01:23,090
Well, the story kind of starts with
a little bit of history, right.

18
00:01:23,090 --> 00:01:27,190
We need to go back, I don't know,
maybe about ten years or so.

19
00:01:27,190 --> 00:01:31,620
Amazon was one of the few
online e-retailers

20
00:01:31,620 --> 00:01:35,710
to survive the dot com bubble
burst in 1999 and 2000, right.

21
00:01:35,710 --> 00:01:39,920
So there were a lot of e-retailers out
there and not many of them made it.

22
00:01:39,920 --> 00:01:43,710
You have companies like eBay and
PayPal, right, you have Amazon.

23
00:01:43,710 --> 00:01:45,380
Companies like that survive the storm and

24
00:01:45,380 --> 00:01:49,448
have grown to become these online
retailing juggernauts, all right.

25
00:01:49,448 --> 00:01:53,080
The last time I saw some financials out
of Amazon, they were showing where their

26
00:01:53,080 --> 00:01:57,620
company dealt with revenues in excess
of one million dollars per hour.

27
00:01:57,620 --> 00:02:00,978
That means they're handling
transactions from hundreds,

28
00:02:00,978 --> 00:02:04,679
thousands of people per hour to
generate those kinds of revenues.

29
00:02:04,679 --> 00:02:08,594
It's more than any other storefront
that's out there, it's really impressive,

30
00:02:08,594 --> 00:02:10,091
the amount of commerce they do.

31
00:02:10,091 --> 00:02:12,590
All right, so how does that matter to us?

32
00:02:12,590 --> 00:02:15,350
Well in order to support
that infrastructure,

33
00:02:15,350 --> 00:02:19,010
Amazon needed some of the highest
level redundancy possible.

34
00:02:19,010 --> 00:02:22,480
They also needed servers
that could handle the load.

35
00:02:22,480 --> 00:02:26,180
The hundreds of thousands of people that
hit their site within an hour period,

36
00:02:26,180 --> 00:02:29,930
not just counting the tens of thousands
of people that actually place an order.

37
00:02:29,930 --> 00:02:31,770
It takes a lot of
infrastructure to support that.

38
00:02:31,770 --> 00:02:35,210
And if you've ever worked in
a commercial data center,

39
00:02:35,210 --> 00:02:37,620
you'll know there's a lot
of equipment involved.

40
00:02:37,620 --> 00:02:42,040
You've got proper heating and air for
all of those servers, the racks.

41
00:02:42,040 --> 00:02:45,920
Just the management piece of keeping
thousands of servers up to date and

42
00:02:45,920 --> 00:02:46,820
operational.

43
00:02:46,820 --> 00:02:48,900
It's a huge maintenance cost.

44
00:02:48,900 --> 00:02:52,824
You start factoring things in
like security guards and cameras,

45
00:02:52,824 --> 00:02:57,190
redundant diesel generators,
multiple internet service providers.

46
00:02:57,190 --> 00:03:02,116
There is a huge burden to providing
a online shop 24 hours a day,

47
00:03:02,116 --> 00:03:04,775
seven days a week, all right.

48
00:03:04,775 --> 00:03:07,465
But Amazon does it because they have to.

49
00:03:07,465 --> 00:03:13,445
If their site goes offline, they will
lose over a million dollars per hour.

50
00:03:13,445 --> 00:03:17,455
So to spend tens of millions or hundreds
of millions of dollars on a state of

51
00:03:17,455 --> 00:03:20,630
the art data center for
them, it makes sense, right?

52
00:03:20,630 --> 00:03:21,735
And they've done it, they did that.

53
00:03:21,735 --> 00:03:24,100
They'd invested in all of
that infrastructure so

54
00:03:24,100 --> 00:03:26,790
that their storefront
would always be available.

55
00:03:26,790 --> 00:03:29,500
And over the last ten years,

56
00:03:29,500 --> 00:03:34,230
you can count the outages that
Amazon has had on one hand.

57
00:03:34,230 --> 00:03:38,350
And during each of those outages
the website was still functional,

58
00:03:38,350 --> 00:03:39,710
you could still place orders.

59
00:03:39,710 --> 00:03:44,230
It was various little components of
the site that had issues, but the primary

60
00:03:44,230 --> 00:03:48,710
functionality has been up and running for
over ten years without interruption.

61
00:03:48,710 --> 00:03:49,620
That's impressive.

62
00:03:49,620 --> 00:03:53,100
There are not many companies that can lay
claim to something like that, all right.

63
00:03:53,100 --> 00:03:56,711
Well what they found was, after they
got this infrastructure in place,

64
00:03:56,711 --> 00:03:59,266
that most of the time they didn't need it,
right?

65
00:03:59,266 --> 00:04:03,110
When they're not having a failure do
you need your redundant equipment?

66
00:04:03,110 --> 00:04:05,560
Most of the time they found their
equipment was just sitting there

67
00:04:05,560 --> 00:04:06,920
not being used.

68
00:04:06,920 --> 00:04:09,709
And so someone,
I'm not sure exactly who, but

69
00:04:09,709 --> 00:04:13,640
someone within the Amazon
executive team had an idea.

70
00:04:13,640 --> 00:04:18,536
And the idea was, what if we rent out some
of this extra stuff to other companies,

71
00:04:18,536 --> 00:04:22,140
companies that can't afford to
do all of this crazy stuff?

72
00:04:22,140 --> 00:04:26,217
Companies that can't afford to have these
massive generators and five different

73
00:04:26,217 --> 00:04:30,010
internet service providers, and
data centers in more than one continent.

74
00:04:30,010 --> 00:04:32,660
Right, I mean this is expensive stuff.

75
00:04:32,660 --> 00:04:34,090
And they said, what if we took that and

76
00:04:34,090 --> 00:04:38,000
rented it out to these other companies,
and now they can take advantage of it too?

77
00:04:38,000 --> 00:04:39,250
And on one hand,

78
00:04:39,250 --> 00:04:42,770
we have our redundant infrastructure
that keeps Amazon up and running.

79
00:04:42,770 --> 00:04:43,450
And on the other hand,

80
00:04:43,450 --> 00:04:47,670
we defray part of the cost by
renting it out to other people.

81
00:04:47,670 --> 00:04:50,500
And that's how
Amazon Web Services was born.

82
00:04:50,500 --> 00:04:54,830
It was a chance for private companies
to take advantage of the investment in

83
00:04:54,830 --> 00:04:57,070
infrastructure that Amazon had made.

84
00:04:57,070 --> 00:04:59,570
Companies like Amazon are interesting,

85
00:04:59,570 --> 00:05:02,120
because they provide an online service,
right?

86
00:05:02,120 --> 00:05:04,130
There is no physical storefront for
Amazon.

87
00:05:04,130 --> 00:05:07,390
You can't walk into the local Amazon store
and buy a roll of toilet paper, right?

88
00:05:07,390 --> 00:05:08,920
You've gotta go to their website and
buy it,

89
00:05:08,920 --> 00:05:13,580
and they deliver it, so having their
website available is essential.

90
00:05:13,580 --> 00:05:16,200
When the website's not available,
the store is closed.

91
00:05:16,200 --> 00:05:18,360
All right, so that's one aspect.

92
00:05:18,360 --> 00:05:20,830
The other aspect is, they're very dynamic.

93
00:05:20,830 --> 00:05:23,510
They have peaks and valleys of access.

94
00:05:23,510 --> 00:05:26,940
So right now, it is, what time is it?

95
00:05:26,940 --> 00:05:28,480
It's 10 AM, US Eastern.

96
00:05:28,480 --> 00:05:32,800
And it might be kind of slow
on Amazon's website right now.

97
00:05:32,800 --> 00:05:35,280
Well, slow here in the United States.

98
00:05:35,280 --> 00:05:38,780
In France, Amazon's website
might be hopping right now,

99
00:05:38,780 --> 00:05:40,720
because it's later in the day, right?

100
00:05:40,720 --> 00:05:42,460
It's 3PM in France right now.

101
00:05:42,460 --> 00:05:45,320
And so
things might be hopping along over there.

102
00:05:45,320 --> 00:05:50,460
So their servers here in the US
are probably not churning along as fast,

103
00:05:50,460 --> 00:05:54,330
or not handling as much as a workload,
as the ones that are in Europe right now.

104
00:05:54,330 --> 00:05:58,320
And the ones that are servicing Asia,
they're probably really slow right now,

105
00:05:58,320 --> 00:05:59,800
cuz it's the middle of the night.

106
00:05:59,800 --> 00:06:05,110
And so they've got these servers with
unused resources just because of the time.

107
00:06:05,110 --> 00:06:08,470
But when the time of the day
rolls around to noon or

108
00:06:08,470 --> 00:06:11,730
5 PM or whatever their peak time is,
they really ratchet it up.

109
00:06:11,730 --> 00:06:15,660
So there are times during the day
where they need a ton of servers, and

110
00:06:15,660 --> 00:06:19,540
other times during the day where they
only need a fraction of that, all right?

111
00:06:19,540 --> 00:06:23,520
And that means that they have a lot
of extra resources sitting around.

112
00:06:23,520 --> 00:06:25,920
And if they can rent that out,

113
00:06:25,920 --> 00:06:28,560
now they can start to make money on these
things that they paid for, all right.

114
00:06:28,560 --> 00:06:30,980
If you take a company like us, ITProTV.

115
00:06:30,980 --> 00:06:31,950
We're the same way.

116
00:06:31,950 --> 00:06:33,940
We have video streaming servers.

117
00:06:33,940 --> 00:06:38,876
And there are times, we find especially
Sundays, on Sundays, people sit down and

118
00:06:38,876 --> 00:06:40,721
watch our shows a lot, right?

119
00:06:40,721 --> 00:06:43,970
They're hitting our servers, hitting
bandwidth, and doing a lot of consumption.

120
00:06:43,970 --> 00:06:47,610
But we find Monday mornings, actually
right now, is a Monday morning, Monday

121
00:06:47,610 --> 00:06:51,860
morning is kind of our slack time, and
we have a fraction of our users on there.

122
00:06:51,860 --> 00:06:56,100
So the servers that we've invested
in aren't working very hard, and

123
00:06:56,100 --> 00:06:58,728
so we've paid for
hardware that we're not leveraging.

124
00:06:58,728 --> 00:07:03,600
Wouldn't it be be nice instead,
if we could rent those servers from

125
00:07:03,600 --> 00:07:07,060
somebody else and
only pay for what we used?

126
00:07:07,060 --> 00:07:10,940
So if we weren't using all of our server
load, we don't have to pay for it.

127
00:07:10,940 --> 00:07:12,940
We just paid for the portion we used.

128
00:07:12,940 --> 00:07:15,280
Well you can't do that when
you buy your own server.

129
00:07:15,280 --> 00:07:18,312
When you buy a server,
you pay for 100% of it, right?

130
00:07:18,312 --> 00:07:21,368
And you have it, and
you have 100% of its hardware to use.

131
00:07:21,368 --> 00:07:24,250
If you're not using it,
it just gets wasted.

132
00:07:24,250 --> 00:07:28,810
But in a shared environment, a cloud
environment like Amazon Web Services,

133
00:07:28,810 --> 00:07:31,850
when you're not using
the resources someone else can.

134
00:07:31,850 --> 00:07:35,500
And so they take advantage of 100% of
the hardware, and you only pay for

135
00:07:35,500 --> 00:07:36,820
what you use.

136
00:07:36,820 --> 00:07:40,750
Now Amazon was the company that
really led this initiative.

137
00:07:40,750 --> 00:07:44,776
You might be watching this and saying,
hey that's great Don, but I like

138
00:07:44,776 --> 00:07:49,674
Microsoft Azure, or, I like HP's cloud, or
I like the Google web services they have.

139
00:07:49,674 --> 00:07:53,311
I forget what theirs is called,
Google Hosted Apps, something or another.

140
00:07:53,311 --> 00:07:57,801
There are many different vendors that
provide it, Rackspace is another big one.

141
00:07:57,801 --> 00:08:00,259
They're actually a great
company to work with.

142
00:08:00,259 --> 00:08:03,340
So companies like that,
provide a similar service.

143
00:08:03,340 --> 00:08:05,253
All right.
So why go with Amazon,

144
00:08:05,253 --> 00:08:07,370
versus these other guys?

145
00:08:07,370 --> 00:08:10,200
Well, really they all provide
basically the same thing, right?

146
00:08:10,200 --> 00:08:13,780
They all provide access
to hosted resources.

147
00:08:13,780 --> 00:08:16,660
Hardware, in their
state-of-the-art data centers, so

148
00:08:16,660 --> 00:08:18,640
that you don't have to create
a data center yourself.

149
00:08:18,640 --> 00:08:21,650
And then, you get access to the hardware,
and what you do with it is up to you.

150
00:08:22,790 --> 00:08:25,860
The difference, is Amazon's volume.

151
00:08:25,860 --> 00:08:30,000
They were the first big player in
this market, and they've cornered it.

152
00:08:30,000 --> 00:08:32,820
They have the lion's share of
cloud services that are out

153
00:08:32,820 --> 00:08:33,820
there on the Internet.

154
00:08:33,820 --> 00:08:36,900
And, when you look at their systems,
it shows.

155
00:08:36,900 --> 00:08:40,140
They've got many data centers
spread across the globe.

156
00:08:40,140 --> 00:08:43,172
A lot of the other providers,
have less data centers.

157
00:08:43,172 --> 00:08:45,672
All right.
Like Windows Azure, they're still growing,

158
00:08:45,672 --> 00:08:49,670
and so I think they're eight data centers
now, whereas, Amazon is far above that.

159
00:08:49,670 --> 00:08:51,020
Let me show you what I mean.

160
00:08:51,020 --> 00:08:53,990
Amazon has a nice little web page,
that you can go, and check out,

161
00:08:53,990 --> 00:08:56,179
that talks about their
global infrastructure.

162
00:08:56,179 --> 00:08:59,114
And you can get a chance to see
where all of there data centers are.

163
00:08:59,114 --> 00:09:03,420
And so they're showing right here in
the United States, which is part of

164
00:09:03,420 --> 00:09:08,380
North America, that data centers
are spread right here across the US.

165
00:09:08,380 --> 00:09:10,240
They don't currently have any in Canada.

166
00:09:10,240 --> 00:09:12,530
Canada just serves off of the US ones.

167
00:09:12,530 --> 00:09:13,920
Same thing with Mexico.

168
00:09:13,920 --> 00:09:17,640
So, although it is North America, all the
data centers are actually in the US, and

169
00:09:17,640 --> 00:09:19,530
they break it up into four regions.

170
00:09:19,530 --> 00:09:23,895
So we've got this US East,
which is the North Virginia region, U.S.

171
00:09:23,895 --> 00:09:27,480
West which is Northern California,
U.S. West Oregon.

172
00:09:27,480 --> 00:09:30,598
So you've got Southwest and
Northwest, and then you've got,

173
00:09:30,598 --> 00:09:34,770
the government cloud, that's one that's
special just for you U.S. government.

174
00:09:35,870 --> 00:09:40,110
Inside of these regions,
they have multiple data centers.

175
00:09:40,110 --> 00:09:41,290
So notice this one right here.

176
00:09:41,290 --> 00:09:42,760
US east, north Virginia.

177
00:09:42,760 --> 00:09:44,200
This is their main data center.

178
00:09:44,200 --> 00:09:47,970
The one in northern Virginia,
which is this yellow dot right here.

179
00:09:47,970 --> 00:09:51,540
That's the primary one for
Amazon web services.

180
00:09:51,540 --> 00:09:53,580
All of the other data
centers were added later.

181
00:09:53,580 --> 00:09:55,500
These were the ones that were added first.

182
00:09:55,500 --> 00:09:58,990
And when it started,
it started as one data center.

183
00:09:58,990 --> 00:10:02,550
But they recognized early on, that
what if that data center goes offline?

184
00:10:02,550 --> 00:10:04,080
Everything in it goes offline.

185
00:10:04,080 --> 00:10:05,850
So they built a second data center.

186
00:10:05,850 --> 00:10:07,170
And where did they build it?

187
00:10:07,170 --> 00:10:08,310
Right next door.

188
00:10:08,310 --> 00:10:11,415
So we actually have, two data centers,
sitting right side by side.

189
00:10:11,415 --> 00:10:14,340
Now you might say to yourself, well,
that's not very redundant, is it?

190
00:10:14,340 --> 00:10:16,610
Well, it's redundant from some things.

191
00:10:16,610 --> 00:10:22,060
So if you have two different data centers,
pulling power from multiple power sources,

192
00:10:22,060 --> 00:10:25,210
with internet connections
from multiple ISPs, but

193
00:10:25,210 --> 00:10:27,800
operated completely independently.

194
00:10:27,800 --> 00:10:31,410
Separate IT staffs, separate servers,
separate infrastructures,

195
00:10:31,410 --> 00:10:33,080
separate everything.

196
00:10:33,080 --> 00:10:36,028
They're redundant for everything,
except for a natural disaster.

197
00:10:36,028 --> 00:10:38,789
If a hurricane, or an earthquake
were to hit one of those buildings,

198
00:10:38,789 --> 00:10:40,610
it would probably take
the other one out too.

199
00:10:40,610 --> 00:10:41,800
All right.

200
00:10:41,800 --> 00:10:46,142
So when you see this yellow dot,
the blue dots around it,

201
00:10:46,142 --> 00:10:48,326
those are the data centers.

202
00:10:48,326 --> 00:10:49,160
Okay.

203
00:10:49,160 --> 00:10:53,200
And you'll see that this one has,
five availability zones.

204
00:10:53,200 --> 00:10:53,720
All right.

205
00:10:53,720 --> 00:10:58,210
The five zones, that means there's
actually five, completely separate,

206
00:10:58,210 --> 00:11:00,100
independent data centers.

207
00:11:00,100 --> 00:11:02,610
If one of those data centers
were to go off line,

208
00:11:02,610 --> 00:11:05,430
the other four would still be up,
and operational.

209
00:11:05,430 --> 00:11:08,090
And of the few outages
that Amazon has had,

210
00:11:08,090 --> 00:11:12,480
they've always been isolated to
single data centers like that.

211
00:11:12,480 --> 00:11:16,416
So that's kinda nice, that they've
got five different data centers,

212
00:11:16,416 --> 00:11:17,648
in the US East region.

213
00:11:17,648 --> 00:11:18,530
All right.

214
00:11:18,530 --> 00:11:19,920
Notice that it launched in 2006.

215
00:11:19,920 --> 00:11:23,060
This was the earliest one,
which was nine years ago.

216
00:11:23,060 --> 00:11:24,940
Actually, wait, that's bad math.

217
00:11:24,940 --> 00:11:27,630
So it was about, it was about
nine years ago, that it launched.

218
00:11:27,630 --> 00:11:31,230
You'll see the other ones
have launched since then.

219
00:11:31,230 --> 00:11:32,530
US West launched in 2009.

220
00:11:32,530 --> 00:11:36,462
Three years later, they built a data
center out here, in Northern California.

221
00:11:36,462 --> 00:11:37,440
All right.

222
00:11:37,440 --> 00:11:41,630
And so that was built, brought up, and an
online, so that if an East coast natural

223
00:11:41,630 --> 00:11:45,040
disaster happened, they have servers
on the West Coast, that can take over,

224
00:11:45,040 --> 00:11:47,460
and then they just
branched out from there.

225
00:11:47,460 --> 00:11:50,724
You've got three zones in northern
California, you've got three zones in

226
00:11:50,724 --> 00:11:54,196
Oregon now, which is up here, and there's
two zones for the government cloud.

227
